title: Edison Police Department asks residents, business to register private surveillance cameras
text:
CLOSE This edition of NewsBreak looks at the re-sentencing of Bill Baroni for his role in Bridgegate scandal and Andreas Erazo admits killing Keansburg girl WJLP/Asbury Park Press

EDISON - The Edison Police Department wants to create a registry of private surveillance cameras that may help catch and prosecute criminals or aid in accident investigations.

The “Community Crime Cam Program” is voluntary, engaging homeowners, apartment complexes, store owners and other businesses as “crime-fighting partners” to help police solve crimes in neighborhoods and business areas, Police Chief Thomas Bryan said in a news release.

More: Bridgewater cops asks residents, businesses to register surveillance cameras

More: East Brunswick home video cameras aid in burglary, theft arrests

"Video from residential and business surveillance cameras may contain images and information that will help our police officers and detectives locate, arrest and prosecute criminals,” Bryan said. “Participation from people in our community would be another valuable tool on our belts, strengthening our effort to safeguard the public.”

If crimes or accidents occur in neighborhoods or business areas, this registry would enable police to request copies of video footage from exterior cameras, including doorbell cameras, to get leads, identify suspects and save investigative time.

Camera locations would be stored in a secure database at police headquarters, and residents or businesses would be contacted only if crimes or accidents happen within their camera coverage areas, said officer Keith Jackson of the Community Policing Unit.

To register, residential and business security camera systems, including doorbell cameras, must be exterior-facing and be able to retain video footage. Anyone who registers may withdraw their consent at any time, Jackson said.

A host of other New Jersey communities have similar voluntary security camera registries, including Bridgewater, East Brunswick and South Plainfield.

For additional information about the program, contact Jackson at 732-248-6462 or kjackson@edisonpd.org.
